title: War Expressions
description: Discover military-origin phrases that have marched into everyday English — from 'bite the bullet' to 'no man's land'!

questions.question: What does 'bite the bullet' mean?
options: Endure a painful situation with courage

questions.question: Where does the phrase 'no man's land' originally come from?
options: The disputed territory between opposing trenches in World War I

questions.question: If someone 'buries the hatchet,' what are they doing?
options: Making peace and ending a conflict

questions.question: What does 'run the gauntlet' mean?
options: Go through a challenging or hostile experience

questions.question: If you 'rally the troops,' what are you doing?
options: Gathering and motivating people for a common effort

questions.question: What military term means 'a period of temporary peace or pause in fighting'?
If someone 'drops a bombshell,' what have they done?
What does 'caught in the crossfire' mean in everyday English?
options: Suffering harm from a conflict between others

questions.question: The phrase 'loose cannon' originated from naval warfare. What does it mean today?
options: An unpredictable person who may cause damage

questions.question: What does it mean to 'stick to your guns'?
options: Maintain your position or opinion despite opposition

questions.question: If you 'call a truce,' what are you proposing?
options: An agreement to stop arguing or fighting

questions.question: What does 'under fire' mean in everyday speech?
The phrase 'meeting your Waterloo' refers to which historical figure's defeat?
If someone 'goes AWOL,' what have they done?
options: Left without permission or disappeared from duty
